And while I love freelancing (and freelancers), this dual perspective has shown me just how often our expectations miss each other.We built Freelance Exchange with Good Growth Hub to bridge this gap. ğŸ“ You can read the full case study via Local Champions CIC (reshared below) â€” but today I want to be honest about the hard truths: the ones we often donâ€™t say out loud â€” about working across power, pressure, and peopleâ€™s real lives.My first freelance job was in 2014. Since then, Iâ€™ve built a six-figure consultancy career and run Local Champions CIC â€” a social enterprise and international consultancy working across the UK and Rwanda.Iâ€™ve also hired & managed over 30 freelancers in the last five years.Hereâ€™s the truth: itâ€™s still one of the hardest things I do.Not because freelancers are difficult â€” but because the relationship between freelancers & employers, especially in small orgs like ours, is rarely discussed with the mutual understanding it deserves.What employers need to understand about freelancers:ğŸ«€ Life happens â€” family, mental health, burnout. Iâ€™ve missed deadlines too. What matters is honest communication. Building systems of access and support is justice.ğŸ“š Clear briefs unlock better work. You canâ€™t expect full payment for half-complete work.The future of work needs both sides to do better.And we can â€” with honesty, shared values, and radical collaboration.ğŸ§¡ Deep gratitude to every freelancer, partner, funder, and teammate who shaped this work. The Iâ€™ve come across numerous complaints on social media about real estate agents in Abu Dhabiâ€”ranging from unresponsiveness and lack of professionalism to outright scams. Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. Instead, if you find a trustworthy, hardworking agent, respect their time, value their guidance, and allow them to do what they do bestâ€”find you the right home.Trust the process, and in return, youâ€™ll get the commitment and results you deserve.What are your thoughts on this? Share your experiences.

As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

The Iâ€™ve come across numerous complaints on social media about real estate agents in Abu Dhabiâ€”ranging from unresponsiveness and lack of professionalism to outright scams. Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. Instead, if you find a trustworthy, hardworking agent, respect their time, value their guidance, and allow them to do what they do bestâ€”find you the right home.Trust the process, and in return, youâ€™ll get the commitment and results you deserve.What are your thoughts on this? As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

And while I love freelancing (and freelancers), this dual perspective has shown me just how often our expectations miss each other.We built Freelance Exchange with Good Growth Hub to bridge this gap. ğŸ“ You can read the full case study via Local Champions CIC (reshared below) â€” but today I want to be honest about the hard truths: the ones we often donâ€™t say out loud â€” about working across power, pressure, and peopleâ€™s real lives.My first freelance job was in 2014. Since then, Iâ€™ve built a six-figure consultancy career and run Local Champions CIC â€” a social enterprise and international consultancy working across the UK and Rwanda.Iâ€™ve also hired & managed over 30 freelancers in the last five years.Hereâ€™s the truth: itâ€™s still one of the hardest things I do.Not because freelancers are difficult â€” but because the relationship between freelancers & employers, especially in small orgs like ours, is rarely discussed with the mutual understanding it deserves.What employers need to understand about freelancers:ğŸ«€ Life happens â€” family, mental health, burnout. The Iâ€™ve come across numerous complaints on social media about real estate agents in Abu Dhabiâ€”ranging from unresponsiveness and lack of professionalism to outright scams. Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. Instead, if you find a trustworthy, hardworking agent, respect their time, value their guidance, and allow them to do what they do bestâ€”find you the right home.Trust the process, and in return, youâ€™ll get the commitment and results you deserve.What are your thoughts on this? As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

Here's the honest part.Over the last 10 years, Iâ€™ve worked as both a freelancer and someone hiring freelancers â€” especially from equity-deserving communities. And while I love freelancing (and freelancers), this dual perspective has shown me just how often our expectations miss each other.We built Freelance Exchange with Good Growth Hub to bridge this gap. ğŸ“ You can read the full case study via Local Champions CIC (reshared below) â€” but today I want to be honest about the hard truths: the ones we often donâ€™t say out loud â€” about working across power, pressure, and peopleâ€™s real lives.My first freelance job was in 2014. Since then, Iâ€™ve built a six-figure consultancy career and run Local Champions CIC â€” a social enterprise and international consultancy working across the UK and Rwanda.Iâ€™ve also hired & managed over 30 freelancers in the last five years.Hereâ€™s the truth: itâ€™s still one of the hardest things I do.Not because freelancers are difficult â€” but because the relationship between freelancers & employers, especially in small orgs like ours, is rarely discussed with the mutual understanding it deserves.What employers need to understand about freelancers:ğŸ«€ Life happens â€” family, mental health, burnout. Iâ€™ve missed deadlines too. What matters is honest communication. Iâ€™ve been lucky to work with partners like A New Direction who led with care, not punishment.âš–ï¸ Many freelancers face systemic inequality. Equity is not charity. Building systems of access and support is justice.ğŸ“š Clear briefs unlock better work. Employers must scope well, pay on time, and model professionalism.ğŸ’¡ Invest early â€” and freelancers often over-deliver long-term.What freelancers need to understand about employers:ğŸ’¸ Budgeting for you matters â€” especially in small orgs. We hire instead of paying ourselves. If you want fair pay, remember: delivery and communication are part of that fairness.â³ Missed deadlines cost more than time â€” they break trust. One late task can derail reports, delay programmes, or damage partnerships.ğŸ“£ Communication isnâ€™t optional â€” itâ€™s part of the job. Up-managing is a superpower. The best freelancers check in, clarify, and flag risks early.ğŸ§  Understanding how public/third sector employers work gives you an edge.ğŸ“‘ Deposits and contracts are valid â€” but so is delivery. You canâ€™t expect full payment for half-complete work.The future of work needs both sides to do better.And we can â€” with honesty, shared values, and radical collaboration.ğŸ§¡ Deep gratitude to every freelancer, partner, funder, and teammate who shaped this work. Letâ€™s keep building better, together.âœ¨ Freelancers deserve more than gigs. âœ¨ Employers deserve more than stress. ğŸ§¡ Together, we can build environments where both sides win.ğŸ”— Case study @LocalChampionsCIC hashtag#FreelanceExchange hashtag#WeMakeChampions hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Freelancers hashtag#InclusiveInnovation hashtag#SystemsChange hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#LocalChampions

I wish to see EVERYONE WIN!2024 figures show 66.97m hashtag#UK residents - with ~4.55% of them millionaires. This figure is projected to decline to 3.62% by 2028. Factors contributing to this are changes in tax policies: abolition of the non-domiciled tax status, and a culture perceived as hostile to wealth creators - UK's transit chart is showing this clearly.Compare this to 3.82m hashtag#Dubai residents with ~72,5k millionaires, about 1.9%.â€‹ The wealth of Dubai's royal family has an estimated net worth of $18bn. So we are talking big! A member on here wrote that one needs MINIMUM 10m nowadays to feel secure - but in Dubai? Even the underworld packs $1.5bn. So wealth is concentrated in the hands of the few - in a small pond.So I pulled up Dubai's chart. HE is MASCULINE 80% Yang, mutable 80% and fire dominant: basically a Sagittarius. Natally (1st pic) has Sagittarius Neptune, Sun, Jupiter, Mercury - in line with the welcoming, international melting pot of different cultures, stimulating environment, relaxed taxation image. Aries Neptune transit will further enhance this, but the Libra Pluto opposition (and other transits) will challenge it too. Sagittarius energy, while visionary, can also be dogmatic with rigid ideological structures that cover up deeper systemic issues. The â€œbigger is betterâ€ mindset can reveal cracks in the foundation of long-term stability. In progressed (2nd pic) the tension is between a strong T-sqare, and a fainter blue grand air trine - Aquarius Sun conjunct North Node (destiny) trine Libra Pluto Rx and Gemini Saturn Rx. Mars (action, drive) long progressed from spiritual warrior Pisces into hands-on, determined Aries warrior.I also see (3rd pic) a beautiful Pluto-Pluto trine on top of the Aquarius Sun, North Node combo: that is creating a national identity based on real Aquarian principles - coexisting in harmony and respecting differences. The road there will require a powerhouse of strategic intellect, sharp decision-making, and disruptive insight: the apex of the T-square is that Capricorn Mercury.For Dubai to achieve true Aquarian harmony, it must embrace radical transparency, decentralized power structures, and collective progress. With its progressed Aquarius Sun conjunct North Node and Pluto - trined by natal Libra Pluto - the city's destiny is to balance power with fairness, innovation with social responsibility. This alignment calls for equitable wealth distribution, futuristic governance, and a shift from exclusivity to inclusivity. By integrating cutting-edge technology with ethical reform, Dubai can emerge as a true beacon of progressive leadership in the new era.

The Iâ€™ve come across numerous complaints on social media about real estate agents in Abu Dhabiâ€”ranging from unresponsiveness and lack of professionalism to outright scams. Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. Instead, if you find a trustworthy, hardworking agent, respect their time, value their guidance, and allow them to do what they do bestâ€”find you the right home.Trust the process, and in return, youâ€™ll get the commitment and results you deserve.What are your thoughts on this? Share your experiences.

As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

ğŸ§¡ Freelance Exchange taught me a lot. Here's the honest part.Over the last 10 years, Iâ€™ve worked as both a freelancer and someone hiring freelancers â€” especially from equity-deserving communities. And while I love freelancing (and freelancers), this dual perspective has shown me just how often our expectations miss each other.We built Freelance Exchange with Good Growth Hub to bridge this gap. ğŸ“ You can read the full case study via Local Champions CIC (reshared below) â€” but today I want to be honest about the hard truths: the ones we often donâ€™t say out loud â€” about working across power, pressure, and peopleâ€™s real lives.My first freelance job was in 2014. Since then, Iâ€™ve built a six-figure consultancy career and run Local Champions CIC â€” a social enterprise and international consultancy working across the UK and Rwanda.Iâ€™ve also hired & managed over 30 freelancers in the last five years.Hereâ€™s the truth: itâ€™s still one of the hardest things I do.Not because freelancers are difficult â€” but because the relationship between freelancers & employers, especially in small orgs like ours, is rarely discussed with the mutual understanding it deserves.What employers need to understand about freelancers:ğŸ«€ Life happens â€” family, mental health, burnout. Iâ€™ve missed deadlines too. What matters is honest communication. Iâ€™ve been lucky to work with partners like A New Direction who led with care, not punishment.âš–ï¸ Many freelancers face systemic inequality. Equity is not charity. Building systems of access and support is justice.ğŸ“š Clear briefs unlock better work. Employers must scope well, pay on time, and model professionalism.ğŸ’¡ Invest early â€” and freelancers often over-deliver long-term.What freelancers need to understand about employers:ğŸ’¸ Budgeting for you matters â€” especially in small orgs. We hire instead of paying ourselves. If you want fair pay, remember: delivery and communication are part of that fairness.â³ Missed deadlines cost more than time â€” they break trust. One late task can derail reports, delay programmes, or damage partnerships.ğŸ“£ Communication isnâ€™t optional â€” itâ€™s part of the job. Up-managing is a superpower. The best freelancers check in, clarify, and flag risks early.ğŸ§  Understanding how public/third sector employers work gives you an edge.ğŸ“‘ Deposits and contracts are valid â€” but so is delivery. You canâ€™t expect full payment for half-complete work.The future of work needs both sides to do better.And we can â€” with honesty, shared values, and radical collaboration.ğŸ§¡ Deep gratitude to every freelancer, partner, funder, and teammate who shaped this work. Letâ€™s keep building better, together.âœ¨ Freelancers deserve more than gigs. âœ¨ Employers deserve more than stress. ğŸ§¡ Together, we can build environments where both sides win.ğŸ”— Case study @LocalChampionsCIC hashtag#FreelanceExchange hashtag#WeMakeChampions hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Freelancers hashtag#InclusiveInnovation hashtag#SystemsChange hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#LocalChampions

The Iâ€™ve come across numerous complaints on social media about real estate agents in Abu Dhabiâ€”ranging from unresponsiveness and lack of professionalism to outright scams. Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. Instead, if you find a trustworthy, hardworking agent, respect their time, value their guidance, and allow them to do what they do bestâ€”find you the right home.Trust the process, and in return, youâ€™ll get the commitment and results you deserve.What are your thoughts on this? As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

And while I love freelancing (and freelancers), this dual perspective has shown me just how often our expectations miss each other.We built Freelance Exchange with Good Growth Hub to bridge this gap. ğŸ“ You can read the full case study via Local Champions CIC (reshared below) â€” but today I want to be honest about the hard truths: the ones we often donâ€™t say out loud â€” about working across power, pressure, and peopleâ€™s real lives.My first freelance job was in 2014. Since then, Iâ€™ve built a six-figure consultancy career and run Local Champions CIC â€” a social enterprise and international consultancy working across the UK and Rwanda.Iâ€™ve also hired & managed over 30 freelancers in the last five years.Hereâ€™s the truth: itâ€™s still one of the hardest things I do.Not because freelancers are difficult â€” but because the relationship between freelancers & employers, especially in small orgs like ours, is rarely discussed with the mutual understanding it deserves.What employers need to understand about freelancers:ğŸ«€ Life happens â€” family, mental health, burnout. The Iâ€™ve come across numerous complaints on social media about real estate agents in Abu Dhabiâ€”ranging from unresponsiveness and lack of professionalism to outright scams. Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. Instead, if you find a trustworthy, hardworking agent, respect their time, value their guidance, and allow them to do what they do bestâ€”find you the right home.Trust the process, and in return, youâ€™ll get the commitment and results you deserve.What are your thoughts on this? As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

ğŸš€ Project Kick-Off Meeting: Setting the Tone for SuccessA well-structured kick-off meeting is more than just a formalityâ€”it's the foundation for project alignment, transparency, and momentum. In the UAE's fast-paced construction and development landscape, these meetings are critical to ensuring all parties start on the same page.Hereâ€™s what must be acknowledged and aligned during a successful kick-off:âœ… Project Scope & Deliverables All stakeholders must acknowledge the full scope, key milestones, and final deliverablesâ€”ensuring clarity and avoiding scope creep.âœ… Roles & Responsibilities Clear acknowledgment of each partyâ€™s responsibilities is essentialâ€”Client, Consultant, Contractor, and Subcontractors must know their deliverables and lines of communication.âœ… Communication Protocols Agree on reporting structures, meeting frequencies, documentation standards, and escalation procedures.âœ… Program & Milestones A preliminary project timeline should be presented, with agreement on the critical path, early deliverables, and long lead items.âœ… Design & Engineering Submissions Clarification on submission timelines, review durations, and authority approval requirements (e.g., DM, DDA, Trakhees, etc.).âœ… HSE & Quality Expectations Align on the project's health, safety, and quality standards from Day 1â€”including permits, inductions, and inspection/test procedures.âœ… Risk & Opportunities Discuss known project risks and mitigation strategies earlyâ€”openness now prevents surprises later.âœ… Authority Regulations & NOC Dependencies All parties must acknowledge the local authority framework, timelines, and third-party dependencies critical to project success in the UAE.A successful kick-off is not just about startingâ€”it's about setting a culture of accountability, collaboration, and shared goals.ğŸ’¬ Have you attended a project kick-off recently? The Iâ€™ve come across numerous complaints on social media about real estate agents in Abu Dhabiâ€”ranging from unresponsiveness and lack of professionalism to outright scams. Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. Instead, if you find a trustworthy, hardworking agent, respect their time, value their guidance, and allow them to do what they do bestâ€”find you the right home.Trust the process, and in return, youâ€™ll get the commitment and results you deserve.What are your thoughts on this? Share your experiences.

As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

I wish to see EVERYONE WIN!2024 figures show 66.97m hashtag#UK residents - with ~4.55% of them millionaires. This figure is projected to decline to 3.62% by 2028. Factors contributing to this are changes in tax policies: abolition of the non-domiciled tax status, and a culture perceived as hostile to wealth creators - UK's transit chart is showing this clearly.Compare this to 3.82m hashtag#Dubai residents with ~72,5k millionaires, about 1.9%.â€‹ The wealth of Dubai's royal family has an estimated net worth of $18bn. So we are talking big! A member on here wrote that one needs MINIMUM 10m nowadays to feel secure - but in Dubai? Even the underworld packs $1.5bn. So wealth is concentrated in the hands of the few - in a small pond.So I pulled up Dubai's chart. HE is MASCULINE 80% Yang, mutable 80% and fire dominant: basically a Sagittarius. Natally (1st pic) has Sagittarius Neptune, Sun, Jupiter, Mercury - in line with the welcoming, international melting pot of different cultures, stimulating environment, relaxed taxation image. Aries Neptune transit will further enhance this, but the Libra Pluto opposition (and other transits) will challenge it too. Sagittarius energy, while visionary, can also be dogmatic with rigid ideological structures that cover up deeper systemic issues. In progressed (2nd pic) the tension is between a strong T-sqare, and a fainter blue grand air trine - Aquarius Sun conjunct North Node (destiny) trine Libra Pluto Rx and Gemini Saturn Rx. Mars (action, drive) long progressed from spiritual warrior Pisces into hands-on, determined Aries warrior.I also see (3rd pic) a beautiful Pluto-Pluto trine on top of the Aquarius Sun, North Node combo: that is creating a national identity based on real Aquarian principles - coexisting in harmony and respecting differences. The road there will require a powerhouse of strategic intellect, sharp decision-making, and disruptive insight: the apex of the T-square is that Capricorn Mercury.For Dubai to achieve true Aquarian harmony, it must embrace radical transparency, decentralized power structures, and collective progress. With its progressed Aquarius Sun conjunct North Node and Pluto - trined by natal Libra Pluto - the city's destiny is to balance power with fairness, innovation with social responsibility. This alignment calls for equitable wealth distribution, futuristic governance, and a shift from exclusivity to inclusivity. By integrating cutting-edge technology with ethical reform, Dubai can emerge as a true beacon of progressive leadership in the new era.

In the UAE's fast-paced construction and development landscape, these meetings are critical to ensuring all parties start on the same page.Hereâ€™s what must be acknowledged and aligned during a successful kick-off:âœ… Project Scope & Deliverables All stakeholders must acknowledge the full scope, key milestones, and final deliverablesâ€”ensuring clarity and avoiding scope creep.âœ… Roles & Responsibilities Clear acknowledgment of each partyâ€™s responsibilities is essentialâ€”Client, Consultant, Contractor, and Subcontractors must know their deliverables and lines of communication.âœ… Communication Protocols Agree on reporting structures, meeting frequencies, documentation standards, and escalation procedures.âœ… Program & Milestones A preliminary project timeline should be presented, with agreement on the critical path, early deliverables, and long lead items.âœ… Design & Engineering Submissions Clarification on submission timelines, review durations, and authority approval requirements (e.g., DM, DDA, Trakhees, etc.).âœ… HSE & Quality Expectations Align on the project's health, safety, and quality standards from Day 1â€”including permits, inductions, and inspection/test procedures.âœ… Risk & Opportunities Discuss known project risks and mitigation strategies earlyâ€”openness now prevents surprises later.âœ… Authority Regulations & NOC Dependencies All parties must acknowledge the local authority framework, timelines, and third-party dependencies critical to project success in the UAE.A successful kick-off is not just about startingâ€”it's about setting a culture of accountability, collaboration, and shared goals.ğŸ’¬ Have you attended a project kick-off recently? Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

ğŸ§¡ Freelance Exchange taught me a lot. Here's the honest part.Over the last 10 years, Iâ€™ve worked as both a freelancer and someone hiring freelancers â€” especially from equity-deserving communities. And while I love freelancing (and freelancers), this dual perspective has shown me just how often our expectations miss each other.We built Freelance Exchange with Good Growth Hub to bridge this gap. ğŸ“ You can read the full case study via Local Champions CIC (reshared below) â€” but today I want to be honest about the hard truths: the ones we often donâ€™t say out loud â€” about working across power, pressure, and peopleâ€™s real lives.My first freelance job was in 2014. Since then, Iâ€™ve built a six-figure consultancy career and run Local Champions CIC â€” a social enterprise and international consultancy working across the UK and Rwanda.Iâ€™ve also hired & managed over 30 freelancers in the last five years.Hereâ€™s the truth: itâ€™s still one of the hardest things I do.Not because freelancers are difficult â€” but because the relationship between freelancers & employers, especially in small orgs like ours, is rarely discussed with the mutual understanding it deserves.What employers need to understand about freelancers:ğŸ«€ Life happens â€” family, mental health, burnout. Iâ€™ve missed deadlines too. What matters is honest communication. Iâ€™ve been lucky to work with partners like A New Direction who led with care, not punishment.âš–ï¸ Many freelancers face systemic inequality. Equity is not charity. Building systems of access and support is justice.ğŸ“š Clear briefs unlock better work. Employers must scope well, pay on time, and model professionalism.ğŸ’¡ Invest early â€” and freelancers often over-deliver long-term.What freelancers need to understand about employers:ğŸ’¸ Budgeting for you matters â€” especially in small orgs. We hire instead of paying ourselves. If you want fair pay, remember: delivery and communication are part of that fairness.â³ Missed deadlines cost more than time â€” they break trust. One late task can derail reports, delay programmes, or damage partnerships.ğŸ“£ Communication isnâ€™t optional â€” itâ€™s part of the job. Up-managing is a superpower. The best freelancers check in, clarify, and flag risks early.ğŸ§  Understanding how public/third sector employers work gives you an edge.ğŸ“‘ Deposits and contracts are valid â€” but so is delivery. You canâ€™t expect full payment for half-complete work.The future of work needs both sides to do better.And we can â€” with honesty, shared values, and radical collaboration.ğŸ§¡ Deep gratitude to every freelancer, partner, funder, and teammate who shaped this work. Letâ€™s keep building better, together.âœ¨ Freelancers deserve more than gigs. âœ¨ Employers deserve more than stress. ğŸ§¡ Together, we can build environments where both sides win.ğŸ”— Case study @LocalChampionsCIC hashtag#FreelanceExchange hashtag#WeMakeChampions hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Freelancers hashtag#InclusiveInnovation hashtag#SystemsChange hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#LocalChampions

In the UAE's fast-paced construction and development landscape, these meetings are critical to ensuring all parties start on the same page.Hereâ€™s what must be acknowledged and aligned during a successful kick-off:âœ… Project Scope & Deliverables All stakeholders must acknowledge the full scope, key milestones, and final deliverablesâ€”ensuring clarity and avoiding scope creep.âœ… Roles & Responsibilities Clear acknowledgment of each partyâ€™s responsibilities is essentialâ€”Client, Consultant, Contractor, and Subcontractors must know their deliverables and lines of communication.âœ… Communication Protocols Agree on reporting structures, meeting frequencies, documentation standards, and escalation procedures.âœ… Program & Milestones A preliminary project timeline should be presented, with agreement on the critical path, early deliverables, and long lead items.âœ… Design & Engineering Submissions Clarification on submission timelines, review durations, and authority approval requirements (e.g., DM, DDA, Trakhees, etc.).âœ… HSE & Quality Expectations Align on the project's health, safety, and quality standards from Day 1â€”including permits, inductions, and inspection/test procedures.âœ… Risk & Opportunities Discuss known project risks and mitigation strategies earlyâ€”openness now prevents surprises later.âœ… Authority Regulations & NOC Dependencies All parties must acknowledge the local authority framework, timelines, and third-party dependencies critical to project success in the UAE.A successful kick-off is not just about startingâ€”it's about setting a culture of accountability, collaboration, and shared goals.ğŸ’¬ Have you attended a project kick-off recently? In the bustling metropolis of Dubai, the real estate sector continues to soar to new heights, much like the iconic Burj Khalifa piercing the sky. Last week, the market recorded a staggeringÂ $4.1 billionÂ in transactions, showcasing the city's resilience and allure as a global investment hub.Between March 10 and March 14, a total ofÂ 3,726 sales transactionsÂ were documented, with sales dominating the figures atÂ $3.1 billion. This remarkable activity reflects not just numbers, but the vibrant pulse of a city that never sleeps, where dreams are built brick by brick. As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

And while I love freelancing (and freelancers), this dual perspective has shown me just how often our expectations miss each other.We built Freelance Exchange with Good Growth Hub to bridge this gap. ğŸ“ You can read the full case study via Local Champions CIC (reshared below) â€” but today I want to be honest about the hard truths: the ones we often donâ€™t say out loud â€” about working across power, pressure, and peopleâ€™s real lives.My first freelance job was in 2014. Since then, Iâ€™ve built a six-figure consultancy career and run Local Champions CIC â€” a social enterprise and international consultancy working across the UK and Rwanda.Iâ€™ve also hired & managed over 30 freelancers in the last five years.Hereâ€™s the truth: itâ€™s still one of the hardest things I do.Not because freelancers are difficult â€” but because the relationship between freelancers & employers, especially in small orgs like ours, is rarely discussed with the mutual understanding it deserves.What employers need to understand about freelancers:ğŸ«€ Life happens â€” family, mental health, burnout. Iâ€™ve missed deadlines too. What matters is honest communication. Building systems of access and support is justice.ğŸ“š Clear briefs unlock better work. You canâ€™t expect full payment for half-complete work.The future of work needs both sides to do better.And we can â€” with honesty, shared values, and radical collaboration.ğŸ§¡ Deep gratitude to every freelancer, partner, funder, and teammate who shaped this work. ğŸš€ Project Kick-Off Meeting: Setting the Tone for SuccessA well-structured kick-off meeting is more than just a formalityâ€”it's the foundation for project alignment, transparency, and momentum. In the UAE's fast-paced construction and development landscape, these meetings are critical to ensuring all parties start on the same page.Hereâ€™s what must be acknowledged and aligned during a successful kick-off:âœ… Project Scope & Deliverables All stakeholders must acknowledge the full scope, key milestones, and final deliverablesâ€”ensuring clarity and avoiding scope creep.âœ… Roles & Responsibilities Clear acknowledgment of each partyâ€™s responsibilities is essentialâ€”Client, Consultant, Contractor, and Subcontractors must know their deliverables and lines of communication.âœ… Communication Protocols Agree on reporting structures, meeting frequencies, documentation standards, and escalation procedures.âœ… Program & Milestones A preliminary project timeline should be presented, with agreement on the critical path, early deliverables, and long lead items.âœ… Design & Engineering Submissions Clarification on submission timelines, review durations, and authority approval requirements (e.g., DM, DDA, Trakhees, etc.).âœ… HSE & Quality Expectations Align on the project's health, safety, and quality standards from Day 1â€”including permits, inductions, and inspection/test procedures.âœ… Risk & Opportunities Discuss known project risks and mitigation strategies earlyâ€”openness now prevents surprises later.âœ… Authority Regulations & NOC Dependencies All parties must acknowledge the local authority framework, timelines, and third-party dependencies critical to project success in the UAE.A successful kick-off is not just about startingâ€”it's about setting a culture of accountability, collaboration, and shared goals.ğŸ’¬ Have you attended a project kick-off recently? The Iâ€™ve come across numerous complaints on social media about real estate agents in Abu Dhabiâ€”ranging from unresponsiveness and lack of professionalism to outright scams. Unfortunately, these negative experiences can make the property search stressful for expats and investors. To help you navigate the market with confidence, Iâ€™m sharing essential tips on how to find a legitimate and reliable real estate agent in Abu Dhabi. Finding the right property in Abu Dhabi starts with finding the right agent. But how do you ensure youâ€™re working with a legitimate and trustworthy real estate broker? Here are some key tips:âœ… Check Their License â€“ Every broker in Abu Dhabi must be licensed by the Department of Municipalities and Transport (DMT). Ask for their broker card or verify their registration with their agency.âœ… Use Verified Platforms Like Property Finder â€“ Platforms such as Property Finder UAE list verified agents and agencies, making it easier to connect with licensed professionals. Always check the agentâ€™s profile and credentials before engaging.âœ… Research Their Reputation â€“ Read online reviews, ask for referrals from other expats, and check their past client experiences. A reputable agent should have a solid track record.âœ… Work with Established Agencies â€“ Choose brokers from well-known, reputable real estate firms that comply with Abu Dhabiâ€™s real estate regulations. This reduces the risk of dealing with unlicensed or unreliable agents.ğŸš¨ Red Flags to Avoid:âŒ Agents who pressure you into making quick decisionsâŒ Deals that seem too good to be trueâŒ Requests for cash payments without official receipts or contractsâŒ Lack of transparency on fees, terms, and market conditionsA legitimate and knowledgeable broker will guide you through the process with transparency and professionalism, ensuring a smooth and secure property transaction.Respect Goes Both Ways: The Clientâ€™s Role in a Successful Property SearchFinding the right home or investment isnâ€™t just about choosing the right agentâ€”itâ€™s also about how you, as a client, engage in the process. Many buyers and tenants unknowingly make the mistake of working with multiple agents at once, or even calling the landlordâ€™s office, thinking it will speed things up. But hereâ€™s the truth: a good agent can sense when theyâ€™re just one of many, and that lack of exclusivity often leads to a lack of commitment.Real estate agents dedicate time, effort, and expertise to finding you the best options. When you spread your search across multiple agents, no one truly takes ownership of your needs. Instead, if you find a trustworthy, hardworking agent, respect their time, value their guidance, and allow them to do what they do bestâ€”find you the right home.Trust the process, and in return, youâ€™ll get the commitment and results you deserve.What are your thoughts on this? Share your experiences.

As of now, in general free zones companies cannot operate in mainland area.However, recently a reform has been introduced under the Executive Council Resolution No. (11) of 2025 Concerning the Regulation of Practice of Activities by Free Zone Establishments within the Emirate of Dubai with the aim to allow free zone companies or establishment (the â€œEstablishmentâ€) to operate in Mainland in the Emirate of Dubai (the â€œEmirateâ€).The provisions of this Resolution apply to Establishments that intend to conduct their activities beyond the Free Zone, excluding financial establishments licensed to operate within the Dubai International Financial Centre.An Establishment may conduct its activities outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate, provided it obtains the permit by the Department of Economy and Tourism of Dubai (the â€œDepartmentâ€) and through for example a license for establishing a branch within the Emirate or a permit to conduct certain activities within the Emirate.In order for the Department to grant a license for setting up a branch for the Establishment in the Emirate or to grant a permit, certain conditions shall be met, including for example:- the Establishment must submit an application to the Department as per the relevant approved forms, procedures, and mechanisms for establishing a branch or obtaining the permit for the intended activity;- prior approval of Licensing Authority (the Authority of the Free Zone that granted the license to the Establishment) is mandatory;- the approval of any relevant government authorities overseeing the activity to be conducted outside the Free Zone and within the Emirate is mandatory;- certain documents such as copy of the articles of incorporation and of the license of the Establishment shall be submitted.To be noted that:- the activity to be conducted within the Emirate must be included in the list of activities that the Department will issue;- license for branches will have a validity of one year and can be renewed, while permit will be granted for a period not exceeding six (6) months;- the Establishment's branch shall not have a legal personality and shall not be regarded as independent from the parent Establishment.

Here's the honest part.Over the last 10 years, Iâ€™ve worked as both a freelancer and someone hiring freelancers â€” especially from equity-deserving communities. And while I love freelancing (and freelancers), this dual perspective has shown me just how often our expectations miss each other.We built Freelance Exchange with Good Growth Hub to bridge this gap. ğŸ“ You can read the full case study via Local Champions CIC (reshared below) â€” but today I want to be honest about the hard truths: the ones we often donâ€™t say out loud â€” about working across power, pressure, and peopleâ€™s real lives.My first freelance job was in 2014. Since then, Iâ€™ve built a six-figure consultancy career and run Local Champions CIC â€” a social enterprise and international consultancy working across the UK and Rwanda.Iâ€™ve also hired & managed over 30 freelancers in the last five years.Hereâ€™s the truth: itâ€™s still one of the hardest things I do.Not because freelancers are difficult â€” but because the relationship between freelancers & employers, especially in small orgs like ours, is rarely discussed with the mutual understanding it deserves.What employers need to understand about freelancers:ğŸ«€ Life happens â€” family, mental health, burnout. Iâ€™ve missed deadlines too. What matters is honest communication. Iâ€™ve been lucky to work with partners like A New Direction who led with care, not punishment.âš–ï¸ Many freelancers face systemic inequality. Equity is not charity. Building systems of access and support is justice.ğŸ“š Clear briefs unlock better work. Employers must scope well, pay on time, and model professionalism.ğŸ’¡ Invest early â€” and freelancers often over-deliver long-term.What freelancers need to understand about employers:ğŸ’¸ Budgeting for you matters â€” especially in small orgs. We hire instead of paying ourselves. If you want fair pay, remember: delivery and communication are part of that fairness.â³ Missed deadlines cost more than time â€” they break trust. One late task can derail reports, delay programmes, or damage partnerships.ğŸ“£ Communication isnâ€™t optional â€” itâ€™s part of the job. Up-managing is a superpower. The best freelancers check in, clarify, and flag risks early.ğŸ§  Understanding how public/third sector employers work gives you an edge.ğŸ“‘ Deposits and contracts are valid â€” but so is delivery. You canâ€™t expect full payment for half-complete work.The future of work needs both sides to do better.And we can â€” with honesty, shared values, and radical collaboration.ğŸ§¡ Deep gratitude to every freelancer, partner, funder, and teammate who shaped this work. Letâ€™s keep building better, together.âœ¨ Freelancers deserve more than gigs. âœ¨ Employers deserve more than stress. ğŸ§¡ Together, we can build environments where both sides win.ğŸ”— Case study @LocalChampionsCIC hashtag#FreelanceExchange hashtag#WeMakeChampions hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#Freelancers hashtag#InclusiveInnovation hashtag#SystemsChange hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#LocalChampions
